question: In which of the following cases would ETOs and ETA at destination calculated by the Flight Management Computer (FMC) be correct?

choices.choice: When the FMC computes each ETO and using the correct GS
When the actural winds match the forecast winds, and the actual cruising Mach number is equal to the FMC calculated Match number.
When the FMC positions and GS are accurate.
When the ETOs and ETA are based on the forecast winds calculated from the actual take-off time

subject: Radio Navigation

question: Radar returns, on a B737-400, can be displayed on all Electronic Horizontal Situation Indicator (EHSI) screen modes of an Electronic Flight Instrument System (EFIS) WITH THE EXCEPTION OF:

EXP VOR/ ILS, PLAN and MAP.

question: When the Area Navigation system is coupled to an FMS, the VOR/DME tuner provides DME information by?

choices.choice: Turning the VOR station selected and automatically tuning the paired DME frequency.
Automatically tuning to the two DMEs that are within range and that provide the best fixing geometry.
Automatically tuning the 2 closest DME beacons.
Turning the frequencies that have previously been put into the system by the pilot during the pre flight setting up process.

subject: Radio Navigation

question: What is the cross track deviation (XTK) indicated on an RNAV system?

choices.choice: The distance along a track between two waypoints.
The distance between the actual position and the great circle track between two active waypoits.
The distance between the air position and the planed track.
The distance between the air position and the great circle track between two active waypoints.

question: Precision RNAV (P-RNAV) requires a track-keeping accuracy of?

choices.choice: Plus or minus 5.0 nm for 95% of the flight time.
Plus or minus 8.0 nm for 95% of the flight time.
Plus or minus 10.0 nm for 95% of the flight time.
Plus or minus 1.0 nm for 95% of the flight time.

question: The inputs of information used to achieve the RNAV required accuracy may be: 1. NDB. 2. IRS. 3. VOR/DME. 4. GNSS. The combination regrouping all of the correct statements is?

choices.choice: 2 and 4.

question: Kalman filtering is used within?

choices.choice: Navigation computer.
DME receiver.
Electronic Flight Instruments (EFIS).
VOR receiver.

question: Erratic indications may be experienced when flying towards a basic VOR/DME-based Area Navigation System ‘Phantom Station’.

When operating at low altitudes close to the limit of reception range from the reference station.
When in the cone of silence overhead the Phantom Station.
When the Phantom Station is out of range.

question: What is the deviation per dot on the HSI when using a 2-dot basic RNAV system in the en-route mode?

choices.choice: 5 NM.
1 NM.
2 NM.

question: Which statement is true regarding a compass when directly overhead the north magnetic pole?

choices.choice: The compass tail points down.
The magnetic variation is 90 degrees.
The compass tip will point directly down.

question: A pilot is flying between two waypoits defined by suitably located VOR/DMEs. Equipped with a simple 2D RNAV system, this pilot?

choices.choice: Enters relative position between his aircraft and the VOR/DMEs on the CDU to calculate the cross track error.
Must update any altitude change in RNAV system to have correct cross track error.
Reads VOR/DME bearing and distance on CDI or HSI to compute himself the cross track erros.
Reads cross track error and the distance to go on CDI or HSI.

subject: Radio Navigation

question: A basic 2D RNAV system will determine tracking information from:

choices.choice: twin DME
VOR/DME
Twin VOR
Any of the above

explanation:
A simple RNAV system uses rho/theta (range/bearing) to define position, which is derived from range and bearing information from VOR/DME stations.

 

A common general aviation RNAV system is the track-line computer (TLC), based on azimuth and distance information from a VORTAC. It is also called the RHO-THETA system. With the track-line computer the pilot effectively moves or off-sets the VORTAC to any desired location if it is within reception range.

This “phantom station” is created by setting the distance (RHO) and the bearing (THETA) of the waypoint from a convenient VORTAC in the appropriate windows of the waypoint selector. A series of these “phantom stations” or waypoints make up an RNAV route.
subject: Radio Navigation

question: The FMC position will be at its most inaccurate:

choices.choice: on take-off
at TOC
at TOD

explanation: The 737 manual quotes that the FMC position should be considered to be the most inaccurate at TOD. the FMC position will be least accurate the longer the time the a/c is out of radio updating range (no GPS input), like in this case
subject: Radio Navigation

question: Concerning FMC database?

choices.choice: The navigation may be customised for the specific airline operations.
Only the performance database may be customised by the company.
Only the navigation database may be customised for the company's cost index strategy.
Company databases and FMC databases can not be used at the same time.

question: The database of an FMS (Flight Management System) is organised in such a way that the pilot can:

Insert navigation data between two updates.

question: Benefits of Area Navigation include: 1. Shorter flight distances. 2. Reduction in fuel and flight tie. 3.No radio contact within RNAV airspace. 4. Improved safety due to more accurate navigation. 5. Pilot choice of vertical and horizontal separations. The combination regrouping all the correct statements is?
subject: Radio Navigation

question: The accuracy required of a precision area navigation system is:

choices.choice: 2 nm
1 nm
0.5 nm

explanation:
There are two types of RNAV:

Basic RNAV (B-RNAV) which is required to give a position accuracy to within 5 nm on 95% of occasions. It is now mandatory for all aircraft carrying 30 passengers or more to have B-RNAV capability within Euro-control airspace.

Precision RNAV (P-RNAV) must be accurate to within 1.0 nm on 95% of occasions. P-RNAV routes are now being established in terminal airspace.
subject: Radio Navigation

question: The IRS position can be updated:

choices.choice: on the ground only
at designated positions en-route and on the ground
on the ground and overhead VOR/DME
at selected waypoints and on the ground

explanation:
The aircraft must not be moved during levelling and alignment

 

If the aircraft is stationary on the ground then only we can update the irs

FMC position is updated inflight not the IRS position

question: The Flight Management Computer (FMC) position is:

choices.choice: The actual position of aircraft at any point in time.
The compouted position based on a number of sources (IRS, Radio, ILS, GPS etc)

Another source of aircraft position; it is independent of other position sources (IRS, Radio, ILS etc).

Outside the coverage of station-referenced navigation aids provided that it is equipped with a minimum of one serviceable self-contained navigation aid.
Within the coverage of station-referenced navigation aids provided that it is equipped with a minimum of one serviceable of self-contained navigation aids.
Outside the coverage of station-referenced navigation aids provided that it is equipped with a minimum of two serviceable self-contained navigation aids.

question: Concerning FMC operation, which of the following is true:

choices.choice: the FMC combines the long term accuracy of the IRS with the short term accuracy of the external reference
the FMC combines the long term accuracy of the IRS with the long term accuracy of the external reference
the FMC combines the short term accuracy of the IRS with the short term accuracy of the external reference
the FMC combines the short term accuracy of the IRS with the long term accuracy of the external reference

question: The correct format for the input of position 50N 00527E to the CDU is:
explanation: Latitude and Longitude as either a 7 group alphanumeric (e.g. N05W010) or a 15 group (e.g. N0926.3W00504.7) Note the leading zeros must be entered for the FMC to accept the position.

question: The period of validity of the navigational database is:

choices.choice: 28 days
1 month
determined by the national authority and may be from 28 days to 91 days

explanation:
The navigation data is updated every 28 days and the FMC contains the current and next 28 days database (this coincides with the ICAO navigation data cycle). The data may be customised for the specific airline operations.

no external data can be uploaded by pilots,  navigational data can be INSERTED but not UPDATED

choices.choice: Use the automatically computed values on the CDI/HSI.
The pilot is presented with VOR/DME information which must then be correlated to the pressure instruments to determine the effect of altitude.
The pilot takes VOR and DME information and computes it himself.
The pilot will have to calculate the wind and apply it to the VOR/DME information.

subject: Radio Navigation

question: A 2-dimensional RNAV system has a capability in the?

choices.choice: Horizontal plane.
Vertical plane.
Horizontal and vertical planes.
Timing function.

subject: Radio Navigation

question: The sequence of displays accessed on initialisation is:

choices.choice: POS INIT, IDENT, RTE
IDENT, RTE, POS INIT
IDENT, POS INIT, RTE
POS INIT, RTE, IDENT

explanation:
First IDENT PAGE

When power is applied, the FMS executes an internal test sequence. When the test is successfully completed, it presents the IDENT page on the CDU. This page contains information on the aircraft model and engine thrust from the performance database

SECOND POSITION INITIALISATION  PAGE

The position initialisation (POS INIT) page allows initialisation of heading and position for the IRS.

 

THIRD ROUTE PAGE

The route pages are used to insert, check and/or modify a company route, or to insert a route not held in the database.

remember I,P,R
subject: Radio Navigation

question: Above latitudes of 84° a twin FMS/triple IRS system will go to de-coupled operations. The reason for this is:

choices.choice: to prevent error messages as the IRS longitudes show large differences
to ease the pilot's workload
to improve the system accuracy
because the magnetic variation changes rapidly in high latitudes

explanation: When operating at latitudes in excess of 84° the FMC will de-couple the IRS with the left FMC using the IRS in the order left, centre, right and the right FMC in the order right, centre, left. Over a short period of time each FMC will change the FMC position to the appropriate IRS position. The reason for the de-coupling is that the calculation of change of longitude from departure is a function of the secant of latitude, which, at values approaching 90°, is increasing rapidly (e.g. sec 86°00 = 14.3356, sec 86°01′ = 14.3955). This means that a small error in latitude will result in a large error in the calculation of change of longitude. This would give an apparent large divergence between the IRS positions in terms of the longitude calculated, although in fact the actual difference in position would be small.
subject: Radio Navigation

The VOR/DME Area Navigation System has its own VHF NA turner and it always tunes the DME stations closest to the aircraft.
The VOR/DME Area Navigation System uses whatever stations are turned on the aircraft's normal VHF radio.

Radial from one VOR and distance from two DME.

A non-exiting VOR/DME station defined by two DME distances.

question: Refer to Appendix A. What are the correct selections to insert the most accurate position into the IRS?

choices.choice: 3R then 4R
2R then 4R
4R then 3R
3L then 4R

explanation: At 4R the FMC is asking for the aircraft position to initialise the IRS. The position could be input manually in the scratchpad then inserted by selecting 4R. However, the database has already inserted the position into 3R, so this can be copied by selecting 3R to draw the data down to the scratchpad and then 4R to insert into the field.

Up to 5 alphanumerics for ICAO aerodrome designators, reporting points, navigation facilities, airways designators (e.g. VIDP, IBANI,DPN,DIG) and runway desigantors

Up to 7 alphanumerics for SID and STAR (e.g. BUTOP5B)

The navigation data is updated every 28 days and the FMC contains the current and next 28 days database (this coincides with the ICAO navigation data cycle). The data may be customised for the specific airline operations.

choices.choice: 15 nm
20 nm
25 nm
30 nm

explanation: Since there are only two range readouts VOR/DME or the Phantom station aircraft will read out the Phantom station which is 20 nautical mile because it is navigating using 2D RNAV system not the VOR/DME ,  phantom station has been created using the bearing and distance from a vor /dme station ,

Don't need to be in range of the referenced station to enter or use it.

question: IRS is a self-contained system because?

choices.choice: The system has a battery back-up which guarantees the well-functioning of the system in case of power failure.

question: The position used by the FMC in the B737-400 is:

choices.choice: an average of the two IRS positions
an average of the two IRS positions, smoothed by the Kalman filtering process.
taken from the selected IRS, smoothed by Kalman filtering and updated to the external reference
generated from the external reference and updated by the IRS as part of the Kalman filtering process.

explanation: Kalman filtering is the process used within a navigation computer to combine the short term accuracy of the IRS with the long term accuracy of the external reference
subject: Radio Navigation
